Context:
The text describes a dental technology program offered by the college. In this program, students learn to use various tools and technologies to create oral devices prescribed by dentists. They will work with full dentures, partial dentures, crowns, bridges, implant-regulated restorations, orthodontic appliances, and other specialty items. Students have the opportunity to practice in on-site high-tech dental labs.

Graduates of this program are eligible to apply for the Canadian Alliance of Dental Technology Regulators (CADTR) Dental Technology Entry to Practice Assessment (DTETPA) and the College of Dental Technologists of Ontario to obtain a Certificate of Registration. However, without this certificate, graduates may only work as a lab technician under the supervision of a Registered Dental Technologist.

The program has an external field component in year three, where students spend two days a week in class and three days per week off-site at an external professional laboratory for approximately 21 hours per week. Students are responsible for organizing their own external lab experience with approval from the program.

Interested students who need to improve their marks can consider enrolling in the Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Advanced Diplomas and Degrees (A108) program as a precursor to this dental technology program.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Dental Technology Program S100 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides information about a diploma program offered by the college with a focus on biology, chemistry, physics, and communication. Graduates of this program are eligible to apply for the national entry to practice assessment with the Canadian Alliance of Dental Technology Regulators (CADTR) and upon successful completion, can apply for a General Certificate of Registration from the College of Dental Technologists of Ontario (CDTO), which allows them to work as Registered Dental Technologists (RDTs).

RDTs have various career opportunities such as practicing the full scope of dental technology in a commercial dental laboratory or in a dental office, owning and operating a dental laboratory that services oral health professionals, supervising the practice of dental technology performed by dental lab associates, branching into other positions like educators and consultants, and shaping the regulation of dental technology.

Without obtaining a Certificate of Registration in Ontario, graduates may work as dental lab associates under the direct supervision of an RDT or dentist or sales representatives with a dental supply company. The text also mentions the required courses for the first semester, including ANAT 1010 (Functional Anatomy), ANAT 1068 (Head and Neck Anatomy), DENT 1026 (Complete Denture Construction I), DENT 1030 (Orthodontics I), DENT 1150 (Introduction to Dental Technology), COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication), a General Education Elective, and BIOL 1004 (Microbiology).

Additional information includes the Transfer Guide for future study options and the CDTO's website for further information about obtaining a Certificate of Registration.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Dental Technology Program S100 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: International Tuition for programs starting in Fall 2022 is $36,091.00. For programs starting in Fall 2023 and beyond, tuition fees are subject to change. There will be additional costs each year of study including textbooks, laboratory attire and personal protective equipment, and rental fees for some equipment on loan to the student. International students should visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information. This program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet eligibility criteria. Admission requirements include an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English with a minimum grade of 70%, grade 11 or 12 math with a minimum grade of 60%, grade 11 biology with a minimum grade of 70% and grade 11 chemistry or physics with a minimum grade of 60%. Mature students without an OSSD may take the Admissions Assessment for English, math or biology or consider upgrading to achieve the required credits. The manual dexterity test is no longer required for this program.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Dental Technology Program S100 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Program Requirements:
- Applicants may need grades higher than stated minimum requirements for admission.
- College or university credits may qualify for course exemptions.
- International Students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
- Special requirements include a Standard First Aid certificate with CPR level C, which must be renewed every three years and annually respectively, and a Pre-placement Health Form (for third-year students only).
- All costs related to health requirements are the student's responsibility.

Application Process:
- Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
- International Students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.

Contact Information:
- For program information, contact 416-415-5000 ext. 2367 or email sdhprograms@georgebrown.ca.
- For general college information, contact 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
- Contact international recruitment representatives through the International Contact Us page.

Related Programs:
- Dental Hygiene (S134)
- Dental Assisting (Levels I and II) (S113)
- Denturism (S101)
